articles.headline: Minimizing Your Own Exposure to Risks
articles.snippet: Consider a few modest but concrete things you can do that could reduce your exposure to four of the big areas of risk: investments, job security, your mortgage and insurance.
articles.abstract: Consider a few modest but concrete things you can do that could reduce your exposure to four of the big areas of risk: investments, job security, your mortgage and insurance.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every piece of your financial life involves at least a bit of risk. What made this week extraordinarily rare, and so terribly frightening, was that all of the threats were on display at once.

articles.headline: Meanwhile, the Other No. 2 Keeps On Punching
articles.snippet: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. has been butchering Senator John McCain this week. It is not clear who has noticed.
articles.abstract: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. has been butchering Senator John McCain this week. It is not clear who has noticed.
articles.lead_paragraph: FLAT ROCK, Mich.  As the economy reels, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.  the Other Running Mate  has been absolutely butchering Senator John McCain across the Rust Belt this week. It is not clear who has noticed.

articles.headline: Rescue Plan for Funds Will Come at a Cost
articles.snippet: The rescue package presents new questions for money market funds and their customers. They may soon be facing higher costs, tighter investment restrictions and more complicated regulations.
articles.abstract: The rescue package presents new questions for money market funds and their customers. They may soon be facing higher costs, tighter investment restrictions and more complicated regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Emergency steps by regulators on Friday to shore up money-market funds appeared to restore confidence in the $3.4 trillion industry, after a week that raised alarming questions about investments that were long considered risk-free.

articles.headline: Hoping a Hail Mary Pass Connects
articles.snippet: The solution proposed by the Treasury, like the football play, is not very likely to succeed.
articles.abstract: The solution proposed by the Treasury, like the football play, is not very likely to succeed.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the end of the worst week for financial markets since 1929, and Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. looked sleep-deprived.

articles.headline: McCain’s Camp Tests Fund-Raising Limits
articles.snippet: John McCain, who championed campaign finance reform, is maneuvering to wring the maximum out of such laws.
articles.abstract: John McCain, who championed campaign finance reform, is maneuvering to wring the maximum out of such laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain toiled for years to push a campaign finance overhaul through Congress. After the measure finally passed, Trevor Potter, a lawyer and vigorous advocate for reforming the system, was instrumental in defending the law from challenges and pressing for strict enforcement.

articles.headline: As Text Messages Fly, Danger Lurks
articles.snippet: There is anecdotal evidence that texting while doing something else is starting to cause fatal accidents.
articles.abstract: There is anecdotal evidence that texting while doing something else is starting to cause fatal accidents.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Senator Barack Obama used one to announce to the world his choice of a running mate. Thousands of Americans have used them to vote for their favorite “American Idol” contestants. Many teenagers prefer them to actually talking. Almost overnight, text messages have become the preferred form of communication for millions.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Laura M. Holson

articles.headline: Bush Officials Urge Swift Action on Rescue Powers
articles.snippet: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. said the upfront cost of a rescue proposal could easily be $500 billion, and outside experts predicted that the bill could reach $1 trillion.
articles.abstract: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. said the upfront cost of a rescue proposal could easily be $500 billion, and outside experts predicted that the bill could reach $1 trillion.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration, moving to prevent an economic cataclysm, urged Congress on Friday to grant it far-reaching emergency powers to buy hundreds of billions of dollars in distressed mortgages despite many unknowns about how the plan would work.

articles.headline: Dazed Capital Feels Its Way, Eyes on Election
articles.snippet: The financial turmoil has left Washington in the midst of a convulsion that both parties are struggling to understand.
articles.abstract: The financial turmoil has left Washington in the midst of a convulsion that both parties are struggling to understand.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The huge bailout of the financial system that the Bush administration and Congress are rushing to draft will leave taxpayers with at least part of the bill at a time when high gasoline prices, job losses and stagnant incomes have already helped produce an overwhelming sense that the nation is on the wrong track.

articles.headline: Details of a Rescue Plan Are Unclear, but Some Already Benefit
articles.snippet: Short-term gainers are clear, judging by the market reaction, but it will take time to determine who the survivors are.
articles.abstract: Short-term gainers are clear, judging by the market reaction, but it will take time to determine who the survivors are.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government’s proposed rescue plan coursed through the financial system like a shot of adrenaline Friday.

articles.headline: Costly Financial Rescue Could Narrow Economic Options Later
articles.snippet: The rescue plan being created by the Bush administration is like the financial crisis it is meant to end — complex, far-reaching and potentially rife with unpredictable consequences.
articles.abstract: The rescue plan being created by the Bush administration is like the financial crisis it is meant to end — complex, far-reaching and potentially rife with unpredictable consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The rescue plan being created by the Bush administration is like the financial crisis it is meant to end  complex, far-reaching and potentially rife with unpredictable consequences.

articles.headline: Bombing at Hotel in Pakistan Kills at Least 40
articles.snippet: A huge truck bombing at Islamabad’s Marriott Hotel was one of the worst acts of terrorism in Pakistan’s history.
articles.abstract: A huge truck bombing at Islamabad’s Marriott Hotel was one of the worst acts of terrorism in Pakistan’s history.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A huge truck bomb exploded at the entrance to the Marriott Hotel in Islamabad on Saturday evening, killing at least 40 people and wounding at least 250, the police said.

articles.headline: South Africa’s President to Quit Under Pressure
articles.snippet: The A.N.C’s call for Thabo Mbeki to step down is a harsh rebuke to the president, who succeeded Nelson Mandela.
articles.abstract: The A.N.C’s call for Thabo Mbeki to step down is a harsh rebuke to the president, who succeeded Nelson Mandela.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG  President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa, the loser in a prolonged power struggle with his rival, Jacob Zuma, agreed Saturday to resign after the top leaders of his party, the African National Congress, asked him to step down.

articles.headline: Administration Is Seeking $700 Billion for Wall Street
articles.snippet: The Bush administration is requesting virtually unfettered authority for the Treasury to buy mortgage-related assets.
articles.abstract: The Bush administration is requesting virtually unfettered authority for the Treasury to buy mortgage-related assets.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration on Saturday formally proposed a vast bailout of financial institutions in the United States, requesting unfettered authority for the Treasury Department to buy up to $700 billion in distressed mortgage-related assets from the private firms.

articles.headline: A Professor and a Banker Bury Old Dogma on Markets
articles.snippet: The Fed chairman and the Treasury secretary have cast aside long-held views about regulation and government intervention.
articles.abstract: The Fed chairman and the Treasury secretary have cast aside long-held views about regulation and government intervention.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Peter Baker, Stephen Labaton and Eric Lipton and written by Mr. Baker.

articles.headline: Death and Near-Death Experiences on Wall St.
articles.snippet: Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers rode similar paths of decline but had vastly different endgames.
articles.abstract: Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers rode similar paths of decline but had vastly different endgames.
articles.lead_paragraph: EARLY last Monday morning, Richard S. Fuld Jr., the longtime chief executive of Lehman Brothers, put his 158-year-old firm into bankruptcy, burying a company where he had spent his entire career.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Charles Duhigg

articles.headline: Your Money at Work, Fixing Others’ Mistakes
articles.snippet: Depending on how the rescue plan is operated, it could bloat our final bill for this mess while benefiting the very institutions that got us into it.
articles.abstract: Depending on how the rescue plan is operated, it could bloat our final bill for this mess while benefiting the very institutions that got us into it.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT looks as if we may get through this weekend without another scramble to save a troubled financial firm with a trillion-dollar balance sheet.

articles.headline: A Bailout Plan, but Will It All Work?
articles.snippet: Some are skeptical of the Treasury plan, despite wide agreement on the need for a broad intervention.
articles.abstract: Some are skeptical of the Treasury plan, despite wide agreement on the need for a broad intervention.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the federal government steps to the center of the financial crisis, devising plans to take ownership of hundreds of billions of dollars’ worth of bad mortgages, a pair of simple questions rise to the fore: Will this intervention finally be enough to restore order? And what will this grand rescue cost taxpayers?

articles.headline: Citigroup: Above the Fray?
articles.snippet: While the proposed bailout and the newly buoyant market raise Citi’s prospects, the large bank still isn’t out of the woods.
articles.abstract: While the proposed bailout and the newly buoyant market raise Citi’s prospects, the large bank still isn’t out of the woods.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOU’RE one of the largest commercial banks in the United States. Your international reach is beyond compare, with customers in scores of countries relying on you for credit cards, mortgages and auto loans. Corporations worldwide turn to your investment bankers for advice.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Eric Dash

articles.headline: A Soap Actor’s Life: As the World Turns, So May a Career
articles.snippet: I’m not a bartender, but I play one on TV. For over a decade I’ve been mixing drinks and serving up small talk on the CBS soap opera “As the World Turns.”
articles.abstract: I’m not a bartender, but I play one on TV. For over a decade I’ve been mixing drinks and serving up small talk on the CBS soap opera “As the World Turns.”
articles.lead_paragraph: THIS past spring, I was relieved to learn that the restaurant where I worked would not be closing after all. After months of rumors and speculation, I was prepared for the worst. Like many of my co-workers, I thought I was out of a job. Yet I wasn’t worried about closing. I feared cancellation.

articles.headline: Foreign Banks Hope Bailout Will Be Global
articles.snippet: The American bailout plan, which originally excluded foreign banks with U.S. units, may expand, a move that could raise its cost and intensify scrutiny by Congress and critics.
articles.abstract: The American bailout plan, which originally excluded foreign banks with U.S. units, may expand, a move that could raise its cost and intensify scrutiny by Congress and critics.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The financial crisis that began in the United States spread to many corners of the globe. Now, the American bailout looks as if it is going global, too, a move that could raise its cost and intensify scrutiny by Congress and critics.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Carter Dougherty

articles.headline: G.E., a Giant of Lending, Is Dragged Down Along With Banks
articles.snippet: Uncertainty over the company’s finance unit may present challenges to its financial performance, its strategy and perhaps even its business model.
articles.abstract: Uncertainty over the company’s finance unit may present challenges to its financial performance, its strategy and perhaps even its business model.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Electric is best known as an industrial powerhouse, with manufacturing prowess in businesses that range from giant generators to jet engines to alternative energy technologies like wind mills and solar panels.

articles.headline: Wall Street Fastens Its Seatbelt, Preparing for This Week’s Ride
articles.snippet: Traders and investors spent the weekend dissecting the bailout and its implications, amid worries that Friday’s stock market rally would prove fleeting.
articles.abstract: Traders and investors spent the weekend dissecting the bailout and its implications, amid worries that Friday’s stock market rally would prove fleeting.
articles.lead_paragraph: After one wild week, Wall Street braced for another.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: In Newest Crisis, Hedge Funds Face Chaos
articles.snippet: Hedge funds, which typically thrive in volatile markets, are on course for their worst year on record.
articles.abstract: Hedge funds, which typically thrive in volatile markets, are on course for their worst year on record.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  Hedge funds usually thrive when markets turn volatile. But even these fast-money investors are struggling to cope with the wild swings in the markets, raising concerns that some may not survive.

articles.headline: Democrats Set Terms as Bailout Debate Begins
articles.snippet: A week of intense negotiation is expected as Congressional Democrats said they wanted greater oversight of the Treasury, among other measures.
articles.abstract: A week of intense negotiation is expected as Congressional Democrats said they wanted greater oversight of the Treasury, among other measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by David M. Herszenhorn, Stephen Labaton and Mark Landler, and written by Mr. Labaton.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn, Stephen Labaton and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Big Financiers Start Lobbying for Wider Aid
articles.snippet: Even as all details of the $700 billion bailout of the financial industry had not been hammered out, financial firms were searching for ways to profit from it.
articles.abstract: Even as all details of the $700 billion bailout of the financial industry had not been hammered out, financial firms were searching for ways to profit from it.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Jenny Anderson, Vikas Bajaj and Leslie Wayne, and written by Mr. Bajaj.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson, Vikas Bajaj and Leslie Wayne

articles.headline: Young and Arab in Land of Mosques and Bars
articles.snippet: In Dubai, religion has become more of a personal choice and Islam less of a common bond than national identity.
articles.abstract: In Dubai, religion has become more of a personal choice and Islam less of a common bond than national identity.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  In his old life in Cairo, Rami Galal knew his place and his fate: to become a maintenance man in a hotel, just like his father. But here, in glittering, manic Dubai, he is confronting the unsettling freedom to make his own choices.

articles.headline: Shift for Goldman and Morgan Marks the End of an Era
articles.snippet: Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley will transform themselves into bank holding companies subject to greater regulation.
articles.abstract: Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley will transform themselves into bank holding companies subject to greater regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, the last big independent investment banks on Wall Street, will transform themselves into bank holding companies subject to far greater regulation, the Federal Reserve said Sunday night, a move that fundamentally reshapes an era of high finance that defined the modern Gilded Age.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Vikas Bajaj
